awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Engineering Alternative Oxidation Activity in A. ferrooxidans For Enhanced Biohydrometallurgy Capabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project will be to develop engineered bacteria with the ability to oxidize the copper mineral chalcopyrite and gold.  The majority of copper reserves are in chalcopyrite, which currently requires smelting.  The US copper mining industry, due to regulatory restrictions, has a limited smelting capacity forcing US copper manufacturers to ship copper mineral concentrates overseas for smelting, which incurs additional transportation and processing costs while losing up to 30% of the full value of the metal to the smelters. At over 400,000 tons of copper concentrate exported annually, this amounts to over $600M in lost value.  In gold mining, biooxidation is increasingly used before other gold recovery techniques are utilized, and increased oxidation rates would expand the use and significantly lower the capital and operating costs of this practice.  In addition, enhanced oxidation would accelerate the development of mining waste streams as biotechnology feedstocks.  This project potentially furthers more economical and sustainable biohydrometallurgical techniques throughout the mining industry.

This STTR Phase I project proposes the demonstration and development of new oxidation activity within bioleaching microbes, expanding the applications of biohydrometallurgy in metal mining. This would permit the application of cheaper, low impact biohydrometallurgical methods for important metal minerals. Currently, biohydrometallurgy is limited by its reliance on ferric iron as the main oxidant. The Intellectual Merit of this proposal stems from the use of hydrogen peroxide, which can enable mineral oxidation conversions and rates that are not obtainable with ferric iron alone. Adding hydrogen peroxide to biohydrometallurgy operations is not feasible or cost effective, however, the genetic engineering of biomining microbes, such as A. ferrooxidans, to produce hydrogen peroxide would be a potentially game changing advance. This innovation will result in the production of biomining microbial cells with an unprecedented ability to dissolve sulfide-rich ores leading to the expansion of biohydrometallurgical approaches in the mining industry.

por.por_cntn:
Several techniques have been pioneered to improve the leaching of copper from chalcopyrite, the world’s most abundant and important supply of copper. Currently, chalcopyrite is primarily smelted into copper metal at great expense and environmental cost. Bioleaching uses naturally occurring bacteria to passively etch minerals freeing the copper metal in a more sustainable fashion. However, these processes are very slow and often fail to recover more than 20-30% of the available copper metal. With copper’s importance for a carbon-free energy future and the increasing reliance on chalcopyrite as a source of copper, it is imperative that cheaper and more sustainable approaches be developed. Oxidation with hydrogen peroxide is one such promising technique. However, this method is not yet economical to deploy at commercial scale due to high reagent costs and operating temperatures. Building on our world-leading experience in modifying the bio-mining organism, Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans, this STTR Phase I project sought to develop a more economical method using engineered strains to produce hydrogen peroxide as a by-product of cellular growth. A. ferrooxidans derives all its metabolic energy by oxidizing the iron and sulfur by-products of chalcopyrite leaching. Together with our partners at Oakland University, we attempted to engineer hydrogen peroxide production during the last step of sulfur oxidation by introducing a peroxide-forming sulfite-oxidase. In this way, engineered cells would produce hydrogen peroxide directly at the surface of the mineral and as a consequence of typical cellular growth on this important mineral resource. In this way, we could develop a more economical and more sustainable process to produce copper metal.

In summary, this project investigated the potential of engineered strains of A. ferrooxidans to produce hydrogen peroxide as part of growth on sulfide ores as an efficient, economical, and sustainable alternative to traditional methods of copper smelting. Our work confirmed the efficacy of hydrogen peroxide and demonstrated that peroxide can effectively recovery copper under the lower temperatures and more mild pH required for microbial growth. However, at these conditions, peroxide was only 25% as effective. We were also able to develop and demonstrate the potential of a perfusion system that used the continuous application of limiting amounts of peroxide. With such a perfusion system, we able to show that even with peroxide was less effective in the short-term, longer-term continuous oxidation by peroxide could still reach appreciable levels of copper extraction, recovering 50-60% of available copper in 7 days what ideal (and uneconomic) conditions could achieve in 5 hours. Therefore, the fundamental principle of using biology to produce small amounts of peroxide continuously to etch chalcopyrite is a viable strategy. Our partner, Oakland University, successfully mined the available genomes of other acidophilic species to find novel peroxide-forming sulfite oxidase enzymes and laid the groundwork to identify and characterize additional candidates. Furthermore, the Oakland team was able to begin identifying the challenges that would have to be addressed to develop a new selection system to use the powerful method of directed evolution to permutate candidate sulfite oxidases for greater reactivity and lower pH tolerance. However, we were unable to make the last leap and demonstrate an intact bioengineered system that could produce micromolar amounts of peroxide to facilitate leaching. This shortfall primarily rests in the need to continue our work to more fully and deeply understand A. ferrooxidans and the other unique and under-studied microbes that participate in the processes of bioleaching and bio-mining. With the development of better genetic tools and a more complete understanding of these fascinating and commercially important bacteria, the implementation of our vision of peroxide-forming bio-mining bacteria will be possible.
